summary: This document is an email chain from August 2019 discussing a conversation overheard by retired FBI agent Jeffrey Carrie at a bar in New Jersey. Carrie reported hearing two women discussing Jeffrey Epstein's death, alleging financial transfers to a Swiss bank account, involvement of four BOP employees, and procedural failures in his jail cell. The information was forwarded to the FBI's Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad for vetting.

persons.name: Jeffrey Carrie
persons.role: Retired FBI Agent, Director of Security & Emergency Management at Weill Cornell Medical Center
persons.context: Former FBI agent who overheard a conversation about the Epstein case at a bar, documented it, and reported it to the FBI via email.

persons.name: Diego
persons.role: Unspecified associate at NYP (likely NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital)
persons.context: Mentioned as the person Jeffrey Carrie now works for at NYP, providing context for Carrie's current employment.

connections.description: Jeffrey Carrie works for Diego at NYP (NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital).
Carrie, a retired FBI agent, is reporting information to his former colleagues in the FBI's New York office.

events.title: Conversation Overheard at De Novo Bar
events.description: Jeffrey Carrie overheard two women at the De Novo Bar in Montclair, NJ discussing the Epstein case, alleging money was sent to a Swiss bank account after his death, four BOP employees were involved, and procedural failures occurred in his jail cell.

events.title: Email Report with Photos Sent
events.description: Jeffrey Carrie sent an email to the FBI with photos of the two women he overheard, including one getting into an Acura with its license plate visible.

keyFacts: A retired FBI agent reported overhearing a conversation alleging financial transfers to a Swiss bank account after Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The conversation allegedly implicated four Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employees who could retire within a year.
The overheard claims included that moving Epstein's cellmate and correctional officers not performing proper checks were 'done wrong'.
The retired agent photographed the women discussing the case and their car's license plate for the FBI.
The FBI's Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad in New York was vetting the information for connections to 'our players' in the case.
